title: shoppers social distance supermarkets queues
story: BRITS are finally taking notice of the governments strict coronavirus guidelines while queuing outside besieged supermarkets.Photos - taken outside stores across the UK - show shoppers following social distancing  rules as they stand two-metres apart before loading up their trollies. The pictures are a far cry from the scenes witnessed at mobbed stores before the government introduced its lockdown rules.Stores across the country were rocked by violence and chaos as selfish shoppers stripped shelves bare and fought over toilet rolls.Panic buyers formed scrums outside supermarkets and queues a , strong snaked through car parks and onto main roads.The PM is allowing people out to buy vital necessities such as food or collect medication, although he wants them to go “as infrequently as possible”.And some supermarket chains have already revealed they will be doing their bit to ensure people play it safe.Waitrose is to begin to limit customer numbers on a branch-by-branch basis.“Shop managers will use their judgment on customer numbers and when the shop is at capacity to manage social distancing will operate a one in, one out policy,” it said.The supermarket is also using “marshals” to help manage queues outside shops andnecessary remind customers to respect the government’s rules.Outside stores there will be signage and a coned area instructing customers to queue, keeping their distance from each other.Sainsbury’s has already said it will also be limiting customer numbers and erecting barriers outside stores and Morrisons is doing similar.On Wednesday photos emerged showing mobs ignoring the guidelines by standing too close to each other as they queued outside packed stores.Hundreds of people appeared to ignore the Government guidelines as they queued outside the Asda supermarket in Linwood, Scotland, at .am.Hoarding shoppers were also seen snaking around an Asda car park waiting in a queue for two hours before the supermarket opened - and one said it was like a “war.”More than  crazed customers wanting to stockpile ahead of a coronavirus lockdown started queuing at am in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffs.Other shoppers who arrived for the opening time then had to wait until nearly am before they could get in because of the rush. One said: “People at the front were swearing at each other as they jostled for positions.“Tempers were beginning to fray and the doors were still shut. It was shocking.“There were people waiting with trolleys as far as the eye could see. I counted at least , but there was more. It was madness.”     Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: uk weather forecast met office freezing temperatures
story: The Met Office has said most Brits will face a cold and frosty night with temperatures falling to between -C or -C in isolated parts of the valleys in Wales.Central parts  of the Midlands will also see a particularly cold night with temperatures around the -C mark.Southern England will also feel the chill with temperatures between just above freezing to -C.Although while cold, Met Office spokesman Dean Hall told The Sun Online that most parts of England would have a dry, clear night.Temperatures are expected to be warmer further north with Northern Ireland and western Scotland seeing temperatures of around -C but there could be patches of cloud and some outbreaks of rain at times.While tomorrow is expected to be another fine, sunny day temperatures are due to be slightly down from today.The top temperature today, recorded by the Met Office was .C in Bala, Wales and temperatures tomorrow are expected to be, at best around C.Once again though it will be a sunny, bright day for most places across the UK.The south and south-east Wales could seem some light winds developing.Further north in Northern Ireland and eastern Scotland while it is expected to be mainly dry some cloud could develop, bringing some rain over the hills in the far north.

title: japan coronavirus explode olympics postponed
story: JAPAN is warning of a mysterious explosion of coronavirus infections after previously reporting low infection numbers and insisting the now cancelled Olympics could go ahead.But this has aroused suspicion among its citizens that the government has been covering up the truth so it could stage the prestigious Games this summer. Just a day after the  Olympics were cancelled, officials warned Tokyo could be hit by an explosive rise in coronavirus infections after  new cases were reported in a single day, bringing the total there to . In light of the sudden spike, the capital citys governor Yuriko Koike today asked residents to avoid non-essential outings until April  to avoid spreading the virus further.The sudden surge has come as a surprise internationally.This is because Japan has so far maintained an infection rate lower than many other countries — astonishing given it neighbours China where the outbreak began. But one reason for the relatively small numbers of confirmed cases is allegedly down to its lack of testing.Despite reportedly having the capacity to make , diagnostic tests per day, Japan has only tested about , to date, reports German news outlet DW.This is reportedly  times fewer than hard hit neighbour South Korea which has seen , cases compared to , in Japan which has more than double its population. And some have alleged the low testing rate was connected to Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe’s desire to see the Olympics go ahead. He has been said to have wanted the Games to showcase Japan’s resurgence under his leadership after the Fukushima nuclear disaster of  and the so-called “lost decades” of economic stagnation.Koichi Nakano, a political analyst at Sophia University in Tokyo, told the Times: “You can also see the Olympics behind Abe’s hands-off approach to the virus.“The recorded infections and tests are bizarrely low.”Today in Iwaki, Fukushima, visitors gathered for a “Flame of Recovery” ceremony that saw the Olympic Flame on display before it was transferred to a lantern at the Aquamarine Fukushima aquarium until next year when the Games will be staged.But conspiracy theories are circulating around Japan that the government was covering up the extent of the spread of the virus.Barbara Holthus, a sociologist with the German Institute for Japanese Studies in Tokyo, told DW: After the Fukushima nuclear disaster, the government initially refused to admit the reactor meltdowns.Today, there remains a great distrust of official statements.The Japanese Health Ministry has strongly denied the cover-up allegation and said it was conserving its resources so it can cope with a large-scale outbreak.A comment piece in the Japanese Times said there were conspiracy theories circulating about alleging a widespread cover up, that people are dying in their homes, untested and untreated and given  death certicates. But the article says: It is, however, hard to believe that a nation’s worth of doctors would be, or could be, silentthe number of deaths we are seeing in Italy were occurring here. While an authoritarian government might dream of being able to control its population to that extent, the reality is unattainable doctors would speak out to prevent deaths — we saw them speaking out in China, we’d see it here.More than , people have been infected by the novel coronavirus across the world and , have died.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus weird britain shopping zorb ball
story: WITH coronavirus masks hard to come by, improvisation is the name of the game.Here we show how people are thinking outside — and inside — of the box to avoid catching the killer bug.A woman left onlookers open-mouthed by going shopping inside a zorb ball in an attempt to avoid catching the coronavirus.Bizarre footage shows her rolling into a supermarket and picking out food to purchase.A ‘carer’ follows her around grabbing goods and placing them in a basket.He’s questioned about her innovative technique and says: “She’s self-isolating.“She’s really germaphobic.”The man repeatedly wipes the zorb ball with antiseptic wipes, in what seems to be a stunt.Other shoppers were left in hysterics as the woman - who appears to be called Tracey - rolled past them into the store.The footage - which was posted online on Tuesday - was taken at a Morrisons in Herne Bay, Kent.She managed to navigate the meat and fish aisle successfully, but got stuck when trying to roll towards the canned goods.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus lift smear thailand
story: A SICK commuter has been caged after smearing bodily fluids on a train station lt amid coronavirus fears.The -year-old was caught on camera licking his fingers before wiping his hands around the lt in Bangkok, Thailand.He also touched his privates and started pressing buttons on the lt before repeating the process in sickening video footage.Cops launched an urgent hunt for the man over fears he may have been infected with the deadly disease.BTS sky train staff also disinfected the lt to curb the spread of the killer bug, which has so far killed more than , worldwide.The suspect later admitted being the sicko in the video after he was found wandering close to the station.Police Colonel Patikorn Sornchai said: We do not know whether he was infected with a coronavirus so we had to be careful while arresting him. title: days for virus symptoms dr hilary
story: WITH most of us stuck indoors as the nationwide lockdown continues, it can be dficult to know what advice to follow.But don’t fear, Dr Hilary Jones – health editor for ITV’s Good Morning Britain and Lorraine – is on hand all this week to cut through the confusion and explain how the virus works and how to keep you and your family safe. Lots of people will have had very mild, or in some cases no symptoms, so it is possible that people have had it without knowing. Unfortunately we don’t have enough testing to know how many people have had it.Q: What is the dference between coronavirus and hay fever symptoms A: Hay fever symptoms are usually itchy, red eyes and, for people who have asthma, some get wheezing. It can also cause a runny, itchy or bunged-up nose. Coronavirus can cause people with asthma to have wheezing but the two main symptoms of the virus are a dry, persistent cough that is new and a high fever. Despite its name, hay fever does not cause a fever.Q: What are the guidelines regarding bedding and towels when you are in self-isolation A: If someone is in self-isolation because they are showing symptoms of the virus they should use their own bedding, pillows, towels and toiletriesthey live with other people. People should also use their own cutlery and crockery. They should visit the bathroom last and clean hard surfaces with a household bleach product.Q: My daughter and her partner are key workers on shts and are struggling to arrange childcare. Is it safe to look after my grandchildren A: If you are over  you should avoid looking after your grandchildrenpossible because older people are more vulnerable and because children can carry and transmit the virus without having symptoms.Q: I’m a care worker and also a carer for my disabled husband, who has heart failure and is on immunosuppressant medication. He has been told by the Government to isolate for  weeks. Do I have to stop work and isolate as well in case I catch the virus from work A: Your husband is in the high-risk group and needs to keep a physical distance from everybody . As you are a care worker, you will be coming into contact with other people but because you are living together you don’t need to self-isolate unless you get symptoms. You still need to care for your husband and you cannot always keep a two-metre distance from him.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Q: I live alone and have had the virus symptoms. I have been self-isolating for seven days. When is it safe to stop self-isolating A: If you live alone, the seven-day self- isolation period begins the day your symptoms start. If after seven days, your symptoms have gone and you are well, you can carry on as normal, evenyou still have a cough. Butyou still feel unwell, you must stay at home until you feel completely better.Q: What is the best way to protect our mental health during lockdown  I have a family member constantly crying and who has locked herself in her room.A: It’s understandable and normal that people feel like your family member. It’s a worrying time for everybody. But it is important to remember the virus is usually a mild illness. Most people will recover. If you find watching the news upsetting then I would advise switching it off and finding something that makes you feel more relaxed and happy, such as listening to your favourite music, getting out in your garden or doing some exercise, which releases happy hormones. You can also call a friend as it can help to share your anxiety.Q: My partner is seven months pregnant and I suffer from asthma, plus we have a two-year-old daughter with breathing problems. We are self-isolating but when should I go back to work  I can’t work from home.A: Your partner is in the vulnerable group and should be staying at home, as should your daughter. You have asthma so you should be staying at home unless it is very controlled. If your asthma is at all frequent, you should not be going to work.Q: I have no cough or temperature but I am suffering fatigue, shortness of breath and have lost my sense of taste. Someone told me these are still symptoms of the virus. Is this true A: For those who have very mild symptoms of coronavirus, some have only experienced a loss of sense of taste and smell. That is not a reason to self-isolate, though. It could be down to an allergy or an ordinary cold.Q: I am due to go for an MRI next week for prostate cancer. I am , wheelchair-bound and have other problems. Is it safe for me to go Q: I work at Royal Mail as a sorter and work closely with colleagues. Now the coronavirus is spreading fast, should I stay at home A: Physical distancing is key to anyone who still remains at work. Your work is important and as long as you are not too close to your colleagues there is no reason why you cannot continue.Think of all the people working in hospitals, at  call centres and all the paramedics seeing patients. They have to work together with many other colleagues, but they will physically distance themselves as much as possible and that’s all we can ask them to do.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus benefits brits economy meltdown
story: NEARLY half a million desperate Brits signed up to benefits in just over a week as coronavirus sent the economy into meltdown.The flood of , people forced on to the dole could spiral as the deadly pandemic gets worse.Applicants face online queues of more than , people while attempting to claim for Universal Credit — the welfare payment which takes in jobseeker’s allowance, housing benefit and income support.Many have said registering is confusing, and that they were timed out — putting them to the back of line again.The sudden surge of claimants heaps enormous pressure on Chancellor Rishi Sunak who will tomorrow finally announce his bailout scheme for the self-employed.Boris Johnson today promised the country will “put our arms around every worker” to help them during the crisis.He told PMQs: “As a society and a country we are doing a quite extraordinary thing.“For the first time in our history, to get through this crisis, we are putting our arms as a country around every single worker, every single employee in this country.It is a quite unprecedented step.”The PM said he was aware of “concerns about the self-employed” and said the Chancellor will be announcing a support package shortly.Mr Sunak last week launched an all-out bid to save millions of jobs by promising to pay  per cent of the wages of staff kept on the books.The PM hinted that tomorrow’s bailout for Britain’s five million self-employed will be on a similar scale, saying he wants “parity” of support.The Resolution Foundation think-tank has warned that some .million self-employed have already been left out of pocket by the crisis.As bustling high streets become ghost towns, many former workers have been forced onto benefits for the first time.Work and Pensions Secretary Thérèse Coffey today told MPs the welfare system is facing “unprecedented numbers” signing up.She admitted the system is “facing challenges” but said it is crucial everyone goes through the strict ID checking process, which has been blamed for the extraordinary queues.Ms Coffey told the Work and Pensions Select Committee: “We don’t want robots to get money which is why we are maintaining verication.”The department plans to redeploy , back-office staff to the frontline as it scrambles to try to get a grip on the huge backlog.Peter Schofield, the department’s permanent secretary, said: “We know our responsibility — we want to get money to those who are entitled to it.“My intention is everyone gets paid what they are due in the time required.”He also hinted that benefit sanctions will be waived during the crisis as the entire department’s manpower is focused on getting cash to claimants as quickly as possible.But Labour took the opportunity to blast the Government over the growing chaos.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Margaret Greenwood, Labour’s Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary, said: “Unprecedented numbers of working people are having to access the social security system for the very first time because of the health emergency.“Not only is there chaos as they seek to secure support, they will be shocked at the low level of payments.”The Government last week announced an extra £billion is being pumped into welfare to “strengthen the safety net”. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: virtual hug light dark place
story: RIGHT now, just when we need it most, we cannot give everyone a warm and reassuring cuddle.So I wanted to give you a virtual hug instead — one that will hopefully bring some light into the dark place we find ourselves in today.We know that all our incredible NHS workers, the men and women grafting in care homes, those who empty our bins, deliver food and vital goods and our police and Armed Forces are exhausting themselves helping others to cope in these tough times.And the hundreds of thousands of YOU who have heeded the Government’s call and volunteered to help deliver medicines and supplies to vulnerable patients on lockdown has made me burst with pride and gratitude.There are pockets of hope and brightness all over the country and I would like to salute just a few of you who are making a dference.From Shetland to the Channel Islands, the generosity and kindness is simply overwhelming.Steve McLeod, who owns Airth Castle Hotel near Stirling in Scotland, has offered  beds to worn-out NHS workers, who need to get their head down after putting themselves at risk on the front line.Restaurants are offering free meals and deliveries to NHS staff and vulnerable people.In Blackpool, Danielle Mellor’s family-run Cube Bar And Restaurant delivered  free meals to those in need after learning they had to shut up shop.Staff at the Taj Mahal restaurant in Biggar, Lanarks, are dishing out free chicken curries.Boss Muhammad Abed said: “We want to show that there is plenty of good left and it’s not all doom and gloom.”He is right.And this sort of kindness is going on all over the UK.The Sun has been highlighting Britain’s Helping Hand Heroes — and each and every one of them is truly inspirational.It is as though in this time of adversity we have rediscovered a strong community spirit.I happen to think it has always been there. It has just taken this crisis to give us all a wake-up call to realise what is most important — our family, our friends and our fellow human beings.In my street we have set up a WhatsApp group so we can all help each other out getting shopping, medicine and simply checking to seeeveryone, especially the elderly and those living alone, are doing OK.And tens of thousands of you have heeded the Government’s call and volunteered to help deliver medicines and supplies to vulnerable patients on lockdown.I have signed up to have a chat with anyone who needs a bit of reassurance.Cab drivers are giving pensioners free transport. LA Taxis in Newcastle picked up dozens of elderly people to take them to the local supermarket and back home again with their essentials.Our youngsters have also been amazing.James Burnett, , from Grimsby, set up a Facebook group to connect people who want to help — and thousands have joined.He has also been taking sandwiches to his local hospital with sister Ellie-Mae, , and brothers Robbie, six and Oscar, four. I know hungry NHS workers enduring gruelling long shts are so grateful to these big-hearted youngsters.It truly brings a tear to my eye and I am so proud of all these thoughtful acts.To raise my spirits, I go for a daily walk with my little dog Angus. I do not see as many people as usual — and I obviously keep a safe distance from any I do — but I have seen a real change in attitude.Everyone now shouts a cheery greeting or exchanges a rueful smile and wave.There is a real sense of us all being in this together.Like many of you, I have been feeling anxious and unsettled, but focusing on the positives has been keeping me sane.YOU are our heroes daily!!! Thank you!!! We love you.KURT RIEMERYOU’RE all truly amazing.SOPHIA GODWINMaybe, just maybe, all of these small but important acts of kindness and that renewed and revitalised community spirit will continue when the virus has been defeated. And remember: We will get through this.In the meantime, it will be more bearablewe all take care of each other.What a wonderful day it will be when we are able to embrace all of those we love and hold them tight to our hearts.­To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: self employed end may cash coronavirus
story: MILLIONS of struggling self-employed workers will have to wait until the end of May to get emergency wages from the government.Rishi Sunak will reveal today the tough news that coronavirus bailout cash won’t be available for them for at least eight further weeks.In a bid to prioritise the nation’s most needy, The Sun can also reveal the Chancellor will target the emergency help at low and middle earners only.The bitter sweet pill comes as Mr Sunak unveils his long-awaited package of support for the nation’s own bosses.An eligibility cap is expected to be set at around the median income level - £, last year - meaning it will include cleaners, childminders and cab drivers but not high earning professions like lawyers or tech programmers.One likely option being studied last night is to use January’s taxfor the financial year - as the new scheme’s benchmark.It comes a week after the Treasurys boss bailed out employees by pledging to pay  per cent of their wages up to £, a month to stop them being laid off.But Downing Street sources last night said the same flat offer to fund four fths of the self-employed workers income will not be replicated for them.There were fears in the Treasury that Boris Johnson had “talked up” Mr Sunak’s package too much while answering MPs’ questions yesterday.The Prime Minister told the Commons that it was his “desire to get parity of support” between the employed and self-employed.But Downing Street sources instead said Mr Sunak’s guiding principle was “fairness” instead of parity.One government figure said: “No matter how we do this, there will be people who fall through the gap. What matters most is we get money to those who need it the most as quickly as we can”.Better off earners are instead judged to have nest eggs tucked away that they can delve into for short-term support.Five million Brits - almost one in six of the workforce - work for themselves.Some . million of them have already been left out of pocket by the crisis, the Resolution Foundation think-tank warned yesterday.But until the brand new system is up and running, they will be asked to go on Universal Credit.The Chancellor will also highlight how he last week hiked the job support element of the benefit to £ a week, as well as point to the series of other emergency reliefs he has put in place, including deferring VAT, mortgage holidays, scrapping business rates and free loans for businesses.Insiders also yesterday claimed the new self-employed bailout has been “incredibly dficult” to set up, and there were also serious concerns about designing a system that took away the incentive to work.Mr Johnson also told MPs yesterday that the Government will “put our arms around every worker” to help them during the unprecedented crisis.He told PMQs: “As a society and a country we’re doing a quite extraordinary thing.“For the first time in our history, to get through this crisis, we’re putting our arms as a country around every single worker, every single employee in this country.“It is a quite unprecedented step. I know there are concerns about the self-employed, but he’ll be hearing more in the next couple of days from the Chancellor.”The Chancellor last week launched an all-out bid to save millions of jobs by promising to pay  per cent of the wages of staff kept on the books.And the PM hinted today’s bailout for Britain’s five million self-employed will be on a similar scale, saying he wants “parity” of support.Mr Sunak also extended the one year business rates holiday to all firms forced to close for the coronavirus lockdown.That means estate agents, hairdressers, furniture stores, sports shops and other businesses forced to shut down for at least three weeks will pay no rates until April .It is an extension of the one-year business rates holiday handed to retailers, pubs, restaurants, leisure centres and travel agents in last week’s announcement.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus cases peak easter uk lockdown
story: CORONAVIRUS cases are set to peak over Easter in the UK, leading experts say.Deputy Chief Medical Officer Dr Jenny Harries said cases will rise for “two to three weeks” then fallBrits respect the lockdown.She said: “If people have cut down their social interactions, we would start to see a change in the graph.“The peak will be pushed forward but the height will be lower and we can manage NHS hospital care safely.”Brits are shaming their neighbours for ignoring strict government rules by phoning cops.Cops have said the  line has become inundated after officers were given special powers to impose Boris Johnson’s string of drastic measures.Anyone who flouts the new crackdown will face fines of up to £, or even arrest. Police now have the power to issue on-the-spot fines of £ for meeting, with legislation expected to be passed later this week.The Met Police confirmed: Police will be out as usual patrolling the streets of London and will use today to speak to people about the new restrictions to help reduce the spread of COVID-.While we fully anticipate the public and business in London will want to adhere to the new restrictions,we suspect anyone to be in breach of the restrictions we will speak to them, explain what the restrictions require them to do and ask them to comply in order to help prevent the spread of the virus and ultimately save lives.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british airways crew stand down
story: BRITISH Airways began laying-off its cabin crew last night.Bosses wrote to members of its younger ‘mixed fleet’ to stand down as it battles to survive.UK airlines have seen their schedules reduced by up to %, and BA boss Alex Cruz publicly painted a bleak future as coronavirus decimates travel plans.Rachael Taylor, Head of Mixed Fleet, wrote to devastated new entrants: “As I am sure you are aware, the impacts of the coronavirus pandemic are affecting us signicantly. As a result of this we have taken the dficult decision to stand you down from your contract and the business. This is known as ‘lay-off’.“We will do this by enacting the ‘lay-off’ and ‘short-time’ clause that sits within your contract.“Lay-off is where you are temporarily not required to come to work so you will not continue flying duties as planned. “You will be laid off during this time, and the company will not be making any pension contributions during the lay-off period.“Please note that you are still employed by British Airways and this should not be viewed as a dismissal in any way.”Staff will be laid off from April , and is expected to last a minimum of four weeks.Other crew are expected to be hit in coming days.The letter concluded: “I want to assure you that this decision has not been taken lightly and I appreciate you will be very disappointed.”Meanwhile BA’s remaining worldwide fleet has been kicking off about safety fears.Senior crew yesterday wrote to BA’s overall crew boss Amy James, complaining about a perceived lack of care.A letter shown to The Sun stated: “From the moment crew arrive at the car park our safety is being compromised - on the bus to Terminal , in the briefing room where we all sit shoulder to shoulder, on the crew transport to the hotel where we sit next to each other, in small galleys with our colleagues, and of course in the cabin where we have hundreds of passengers that we spend hours in contact with.”It leaves the prospect of BA struggling to fill staff roles on remaining flights.Aviation sources were last night predicting air space could be closed to commercial jets on March , grounding the aviation industry.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: testing coronavirus mess normality
story: IT’S been crystal clear from the beginning that widespread testing is the only way out of the coronavirus mess.South Korea and Germany — two countries that have thrown the kitchen sink at testing — have some of the lowest death rates in the world. And by the looks of things, they’re already flattening that infamous curve. Now, our Government must follow where they’ve led.Yes, we understand that there are global shortages of some types of tests. And it’s no one’s fault that we’re stuck in a bottleneck.But there are other tests that we could and should be rolling out as quickly as possible. Including the one for anti-bodies, which — when it’s ready — will showsomeone’s had the virus and canto work.We wholeheartedly support the Government’s lockdown for now. It’s the only way to stop the NHS collapsing.Butit goes on too long, it will kill both our economy and our spirit.Testing is the best route back to normality. So from today, our motto must be test, test and test some more.THE British public always pulls together when needed. And so it has again. More than , volunteers have signed up in just  hours to support the NHS in helping vulnerable people who have been told not to leave their homes, smashing the original Government target of ,.These phenomenal people — doubtless including many Sun readers — are scared for their own futures. But are laying those fears aside while they do their bit for the country.If you’re fit and healthy, why not join them  Ornot, show your support from home.At pm tonight, you’re invited to open your windows and doors and make some noise for the doctors, nurses, carers, GPs and pharmacists.These men and women are putting their own lives at risk every day to protect us. And they need a boost to keep them going.Joining the country in a round of applause might not seem like much.But it will be music to the ears of our exhausted heroes.CLOSING pubs and clubs was necessary to slow the spread of this deadly virus. But there’s no doubt about it: many lives are poorer without them.So cheers to Robert Jenrick, the Communities Minister who has added off- licences to the Government’s list of businesses essential to keep the country running during the coronavirus crisis.With so many parents pressed into long days of home-schooling, we have a feeling there will be no shortage of customers.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: endometriosis mum hole stomach operation glasgow
story: Rachel Grant, , a beautician from Glasgow, Scotland, was diagnosed with endometriosis when she was , and has since had  operations  to help her live a normal le with children Ava,  and Harris, , and her partner Mark, .In , her abdomen reopened after she was discharged from an operation - and Rachel contracted sepsis.She spent six weeks with a cm hole in her abdomen - she had a hysterectomy last year in what was supposed to be a final cure which still has not worked.The mother-of-two is now raising awareness for the condition as she faces her th major surgery which leaves her unable to work and in constant pain – which is now continuous because she can no longer get treatment whilst COVID- rips through hospitals.Rachel said: “I have a history of this condition in the family but never expected to get it at  because usually it doesn’t effect women until they’re older.“I was in all sorts of pain when I was growing up, and after my first surgery when I was , when the pain persisted, I was sent to a psychiatrist because they thought I was making it up.“From the ages of  all the way until now, I have had  major surgeries on my uterus and stomach, as well as a hysterectomy recently.“Before I had the hysterectomy I had to lose nine stone, which I did naturally, and I thought the nightmare would finally be over.“After one of my laparoscopies I was at home and I stood up and looked down and there was blood all over the floor. The wound they had cut in my stomach had opened up and I was rushed to hospital.“Because of the size of the wound they could not seal it and it was left open for six weeks with just a bandage over it.It is a long term condition that can affect women of any age.Symptoms can y but the main ones are:“I was walking around a hospital and my stomach was wide open.“Nobody can work out what is wrong with me specically, the laparoscopies are supposed to manage the condition, but they don’t work for me, I have one every three or four months.“I can’t work, I can’t seem to be cured and because of this it’s impossible to have a normal le.“As a result of all of this I now have other conditions, insomnia is one of them, which means I can only sleep for three hours a night.“It has been exhausting, luckily I had two natural pregnancies with my partner before my hysterectomy, so I became a mother before things got too risky, eventually becoming impossible for me to do so.“It’s not that I blame the doctors, everyone I have dealt with has always been great, but there must be more research on this condition so mothers like me can recover.”One of the hardest moments for Rachel, she says, is when her laparoscopy wound re-opened at home.She was recovering and with her friends when she stood up and her two friends went “ghost white”.She said: “Because I had only just had the operation, I couldn’t feel anything when I stood up, my friends nearly fainted, I looked down, and all I could see was blood.“I got to hospital and they couldn’t sew it up because the wound was so big so they used a vacuum bandage – which essentially forces my stomach back together.“It looks like a botched tummy-tuck, but it saved my le so I can’t be angry about it, at that point doctors cared about saving my le and not how I looked.”Now, at , Rachel is still unable to get a permanent fix and is currently left in limbo, unable to get treatment for the foreseeable future due to the global COVID- pandemic which is stopping doctors from being able to see her.Rachel said: “I’m supposed to have an operation every few months but I have to self-isolate becauseI catch the virus it could kill me due my current health state.“At the moment it looks like I’m going to have to wait around  months, which will mean I’ll have waited  months for an operation.“That is double the amount of time I usually have to wait, and the pain is becoming unbearable.“What we need is more people paying attention to how damaging this condition is, rather than just managing It, we need to find a cure because for me managing it is not good enough.

title: car engineers use high tech 3d printer
story: CUPRA, which is the performance arm of SEAT, is using state-of-the-art multi-jet fusion technology to fashion parts in a fast and efficient way.For its new Leon Competición model, they have D printed the racer’s door mirror, air intakes and cooling intakes.The process of printing a mirror can take around  hours, but as they can print six at a time it gives the team the ability to create dferent designs simultaneously.This way they can quickly test the ying prototypes in a wind tunnel to find out which is best for aerodynamics.When taken to this controlled environment, the printed parts are fitted to the car and face winds of more than mph while sensors study the impact on inidual surfaces.The cars resistance data is displayed on screen and the engineers and designers compare the results for the dferent printed wing mirrors and grilles.As the smallest margins can make the dference in motorsport, it is crucial the D printed parts play their part in reducing fuel consumption while also increasing stability, speed and safety.Xavi Serra, head of technical development at CUPRA Racing, said: “For the new CUPRA Leon Competición we modelled the steering wheels centre control module, the bonnet air vents, door mirrors and the brake and water cooling inlets.“The main goal is to have a lot of parts in a short time. We can quickly test a wide iety of designs and furthermore, since vehicle development is now done in parallel, this technology enables us to react swtly to any changes in the design process.“The bigger the iety of parts we can test in this facility, the better. It enables us to make much faster progress.“The results were excellent, and some were even surprising, because we were looking to push the material to its limits.“This technology is and will continue to be key in countless fields to make the most complex ideas a reality.”The final development of the D printed parts was on a racing circuit, with CUPRA testing the Leon Competición on the Portimao track in Portugal.So far, CUPRA has been printing parts for its Leon Competición, its mph touring car inspired by the new Seat Leon family hatchback, and the e-Racer, an electric touring car which does -mph in . seconds.CUPRA has released footage of the printing and test processes of the project, which is in partnership with HP.Virginia Palacios, head of systems product management, D Printing  Digital Manufacturing, HP Inc, said: “The work with CUPRA demonstrates the power of D printing and digital manufacturing - changing the way the world designs and manufactures.“D printing is going to signal a turning point in the automotive industry by accelerating lead times and HP D technology is helping designers create parts that could not be produced with other technologies.”

title: coronavirus finger prick home tests
story: NewsCoronavirus: Finger-prick home tests could be approved by end of this weekNational Infection Service chief Sharon Peacock said the antibody tests, which showyou have already had the deadly virus, could be delivered to homes via Amazon - though you wont be able to order them quite yetShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorJamie Hawkins:,  MAR NewsThe finger-prick test will establish whether you have already had coronavirus " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHome test kits which establishyouaposve already had coronavirus could be approved by the end of the week, a top health official has declared.The finger-prick tests would establish whether people have already had coronavirus and developed immunity.Sharon Peacock, interim director of the National Infection Service, told MPs millions of the antibody tests had been ordered  - and a sample of them are being urgently evaluated at a centre in Oxford. Depending on their exact form, some might be able to be administered without leaving home. Prof Peacock said patients could eventually get the test delivered from Amazon or by visiting Boots to showthey have immunity. But Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty warned people wonapost simply be able to order them next week.  He said they must be rolled out in a graded way with NHS staff and key workers being tested for immunity first - and while carefully gathering data on what proportion of the population might be immune. Prof Whitty said: “I do not think, and I want to be clear, that this is something we’ll suddenly be ordering on the internet next week. “We need to go through the evaluation, then the first critical uses, and then spread it out from that point of view. We need to do that in a systematic way.” The tests are designed to establish whether people have previously been infected with coronavirus, as opposed to antigen tests which showsomeone has the virus as they areexperiencing symptoms of COVID-, the disease caused by the coronavirus.These are brand new products. We have to be clear they work as they are claimed to do, Prof Peacock told MPs. Once they have been tested, and that will happen this week, once the bulk of tests arrive, they will be distributed into the community, she said, adding that the they could be delivered via Amazon. Testing the test is a small matter, and I would anticipate that it would be done by the end of this week. She said there were ious dferent models, and some might might require people to go to a high street chemist.  Prof Peacock said she thought any charge for the tests would be minimal and though she declined to say they would be available by next week, she confirmed that they would be ready in days rather than weeks or months. Asked when they would be rolled out more widely she cautioned: “I think I would be somewhat less categorical about the date.  “But in the near future people will be able to order a test that they can test themselves, or go to Boots or somewhere similar to have their finger prick test done.” She told MPs on the Commons Science and Technology Committee the finger-prick test “looks like a pregnancy test”, but using a drop of blood. She added: “.million have been ordered and further millions are being ordered today. “But we do need to make sure we understand how they operate because these are brand new tests, they haven’t been used by us before.”  Prof Peacock explained: “We are developing home testing so people who have been sick can be tested for the presence of antibodies.  “So thatthey’re positive, they can then go out and go back to work.” She said they will be rolled out into the community once PHE are sure they work. She added: ”These are brand new products. We have to be clear they work as they are claimed to do. Once they have been tested, and that will happen this week, then once the bulk of tests arrive, they will be distributed into the community.

The man, named as Dan from Leytonstone, east London, told a radio phone-in he was having to go against my morals to pay the mortgage and feed his toddler daughter.Danaposs case was raised by Jeremy Corbyn in Parliament as an example of self-employed people making impossible choices in the coronavirus pandemic.million self-employed people have been left without full government support for several days despite a UK lockdown. And many construction workers in particular have been told to carry on going to work.The worker told LBCaposs Nick Ferrari: “I’m currently not well. I should be in quarantine. But I work in the construction industry - and I’m on my way into work.I think it may be five or six dferent construction sites throughout the day.” Told he could unwittingly be killing people, Dan - who said his monthly income was several thousand pounds, but disappears on regular outgoings - replied: % and it’s disgusting. But unfortunately it’s human nature, when you come down to the crunch you put yourself first. And I’m definitely going to put myself and my daughter and my we first.Dan could likely access a three-month payment holiday on his mortgage, because itaposs available for all residential mortgages of people hit by the coronavirus.He did not describe his symptoms, buthe had a fever or cough, he is directly defying strict government orders. The governmentaposs advice says entire households must isolate for  daysone of them falls ill. People who are caught defying orders to be tested, or stay in isolation, can be fined up to £, under new police powers to be passed into law today. Despite Danaposs case going against the governmentaposs orders, it does also expose a huge gap in support for the self-employed.  Self-employed people are not eligible either for a guarantee of % of wages, up to a cap of £, a month, or Statutory Sick Pay.Instead they must claim a beefed-up version of Universal Credit, with half a million people doing so in nine days.The benefit itself has not collapsed, but a website asking people to prove their identity has seen queues of tens of thousands of people. Danaposs case also raises the thorny issue of construction workers still heading in on the job after the government said non-essential work could continue. Calling on the government to act, Dan told LBC: I want them to hear that I’m not going to be the only person doing this now. New measures for the self-employed will be unveiled by the Chancellor tomorrow afternoon, the Mirror understands.But Dan told LBC that eventhe support matched the £,-a-month cap for the self-employed, it wouldn’t even be half my monthly income. He added his outgoings are high and I’ve got quite a large mortgage, I’ve got other things like a car. He told LBC: I don’t want to work feeling like this. I really don’t feel well. My we isn’t well. But he added: “I know I’m wrong but I’ve also got a two year old daughter. I’ve got a mortgage, I’ve got a we, I am self employed as well. There’s nothing I can do and honestly I’m sitting here and I feel so guilty.” Askedhe could go a month without income he said: No.Jeremy Corbyn raised the case at PMQs, saying: We heard this morning on the radio a call from a self-employed construction worker who said he had contracted coronavirus, he was suffering from it, he knew heaposs got it. But [he] had no other option to get on the London Tube and go onto a site to work - obviously putting himself at greater risk and putting all other passengers and all other workers on that site at risk. The man did not explicitly say his illness was coronavirus - community testing is not available - and did not specy whether he had travelled on the Tube. Mr Corbyn went on: Why was he doing it  Because his site had not been closed down, he had no other source of income to feed his family, so heaposs going to work making all of us more at risk as a result. So can the Prime Minister be absolutely clear and give unequivocal guidance now that construction work on non-emergency work should stop now.

story: NewsCoronavirus forces UK city to declare major incident as they fight outbreakThe disease has led to an unprecedented demand for multi-agency activity, which is beyond the scope of business-as usual operations in Staffordshire and Stoke-on-TrentShareCommentsByTom Burnett:,  MAR NewsA major incident has been declared in a UK city amid the coronavirus pandemic " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A aposmajor incidentapos has been declared in a UK city as local authorities continue to tackle the coronavirus pandemic.The outbreak of the deadly disease has led to aposunprecedented demand for multi-agency activity, which is beyond the scope of business-as usual operationsapos in Staffordshire and Stoke-on-Trent. In Stoke-on-Trent, nine people tested positive for coronavirus as of Tuesday, and  in Staffordshire.However, StokeonTrentLive reports that the numbers could be even higher due to limited testing.Dr Richard Harling, the Director for Health and Care at Staffordshire County Council is chairing the Strategic Coordinating Group, which is overseeing the multi-agency response, said: “Everyone is now aware that we are facing a unique challenge, with the Government addressing the nation on a daily basis.Do you have a coronavirus story to share  Email webnews@mirror“Declaring a Major Incident now is a way of making sure all public sector agencies and our partners can work together, share resources where necessary, and better anticipate and deal with challenges. “It is something we prepare for and practice regularly. It does not confer any special powers or change the roles of the dferent organisations involved. “This is a sensible step as we know from other countries that dealing with Coronavirus COVID- is going to take time and persistence. “Pooling resources is important because we know we will face challenges, particularly the likelihood that more staff will be self-isolating in the coming weeks and that will strain resources. We will be better able to do things jointly, such as and informing people in relation to any particular localised issues. “Working together is something that we do all the time in Staffordshire and Stoke-on-Trent and the action we are now taking is simply aimed at making that process even more joined-up. “It is important that people continue following the advice from Public Health England and the Government.”  Two pieces of emergency legislation - the Coronavirus Act  and the Contingencies Fund Act  - have been granted royal assent, as the government continues to tackle the pandemic.In his daily briefing Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the country is coping “very well” in the face of the “most challenging circumstances”.Replying to a question about how well the country was coping, Mr Johnson said that “never in our history has the Goverment put its arms around people in the way we are doing now to help them get through this time”. He added that a tailored package of support would be announced on Thursday to help self-employed people. The PM said: “I do think when you look at the sheer scale of what the Government is doing to get this country through, we will cope and are coping very well indeed under the most challenging possible circumstances. “To come out of it well together as I know we can, we all need to follow the instructions the Government have given and to stay at home, protect the NHS and that’s the way to save lives.” Boris Johnson said , people have volunteered to help vulnerable people in the coronavirus national effort. story: NewsCoronavirus: Healthy -year-old rushed to hospital shares daily symptoms diaryThe teen from Oldham, Greater Manchester, had no underlying conditions but still fell severely ill with the bug that has killed hundreds around the UKShareCommentsByRebecca Day:,  MAR NewsThe teenage boy was rushed to hospital after contracting Covid- " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA healthy UK teen diagnosed with coronavirus has shared his symptoms diary to show other youngsters they must take the pandemic seriously. The teenager from Oldham, Greater Manchester, was rushed to hospital by paramedics after falling severely ill with Covid- symtpoms. The teen, who has no underlying health conditions, was in and out of Royal Oldham Hospital over a period of six days as he battled the virus. The teen, who asked not to be named, wants to thank the medical staff for the fantastic care he received. But he also wants to warn young people to not be complacent - as they may not suffer mild symptoms. Eventhey do have a milder illness, they could still pass the virus that has already killed hundreds in Britain on to someone more vulnerable.Thee teenager outlined for the Manchester Evening News what happened to him in his own words.Tuesday, March  On Tuesday, I was burning up. I felt hot then it went away. Wednesday, March  I began feeling ill. I had muscle cramps and aches, I felt really drowsy. Thursday, March  On Thursday morning I woke up at .am shaking, I went freezing cold. I woke up and took a big breath, but I couldnapost catch a breath. I was breathing in and out no air was going in. It was the most horrible feeling Iaposve ever had, I didnapost have a clue what was going on. I called . An ambulance came, I couldnapost breathe properly. I was freezing and had a temperature of .C. When the paramedics came I felt better. I was still shaking, I didnapost want to go to hospital but I did because of the symptoms. They controlled my breathing with breathing exercises. When I arrived at hospital I went through to a nurse.  They said they didnapost know what it was. They all had masks and gloves on and aprons. But it wasnapost a coronvirus ward, it was AE. They were working so hard. I began to feel better. I self-discharged while waiting for a doctor. I felt fine, I wanted to go home. I went back home on Thursday afternoon. It got to .pm. The shaking started again, I felt dizzy and nauseous on top of everything, and my temperature came back. I couldnapost stop shaking, I felt really cool. My dad took me back to hospital, he drove me. We didnapost know what it was.I had bloods taken, then I was taken to the Acute Medical Unitward.I had my own room, they thought it was viral meningitis. I was given an IV drip of fluids with antibiotics for bacterial meningitis as a precaution. I was kept in overnight. I had swabs taken for MRSA as standard. Friday, March  I woke up feeling better Friday. I was better but not pc. I went home Friday afternoon. Saturday, March  I began feeling better. Sunday, March I woke up on Sunday feeling groggy, and got a call from a doctor, telling me I had tested positive for coronavirus.The test was taken when from the swab when I was tested for MRSA. I had to go back to hospital on Sunday night. I suffered a constant headache, shaking and dizziness. They kept me in the Sunday night. I went to a side room at the AMU.  The doctors and nurses came in with masks. They gave me IV fluids and checked my temperature. It was on and off, really weird. I left the Monday afternoon. A warning to others The patient said he now feels better. He felt aposvery tiredapos for a while but he is now aposright as rainapos. When he recovered fully he went to the AMU ward with five bags full of shopping, to say thanks to the medics that cared for him. No one in his household suffered any symptoms but they have all been in self-isolation as per government guidance.

However, experts told MPs that Brits will only be allowed outside againthe Government made more virus tests available. They expect the outbreak here to peak in three weeks. British scientists are among those scrutinising data out of the country where the pandemic emerged in Wuhan in December, the city has been in lockdown since January but restrictions were loosened this week. It comes after a separate study by Oxford University suggested many more Brits may have been infected but developed no symptoms. The optimistic modelling theory suggests the virus was circulating in the UK by mid-January, around two weeks before the first reported case here. If true it would mean more than half of the population are likely to have had Covid- and be immune to it. China is ahead of all other countries and spread of the disease there has slowed signicantly. Mass gatherings are still banned. Author Prof Neil Ferguson, of Imperial College London, who is advising the UK government, said: “This provides hope for countries currently in ious levels of lockdown.” It was not all good news though as a separate study warned that China can expect a second wave of infections by August after it lted restrictions in Hubei province. Peer-reviewed modelling published in the Lancet Public Health journal found that delaying reopening schools and workplaces a month until April would delay the second wave from hitting until October. Dr Kiesha Prem, of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said: “The measures the city of Wuhan has put in place have helped to control the outbreak. However, the city now needs to be careful to avoid prematurely lting physical distancing measures, because that could lead to an earlier secondary peak.”The UK is currently only testing a fth of the , daily checks promised by Boris Johnson last week and lags behind other countries such as South Korea, Germany, Italy and Norway. Prof Ferguson, who is recovering from Covid- himself, told MPs yesterday via video link that any lting of restrictions would require widespread testing. Sir Patrick Vallance, the Government’s Chief Scientic Officer, told MPs: “I wish we had more tests available.” Prof Sharon Peacock, of Public Health England, admitted the , daily test total will not be hit until the “end of April”. Prof Ferguson, expects transmission to be reduced in the summer months by %-%. The only long term “exit strategy” from current lockdown is the development of a vaccine, which could take between  and  months.  The Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness and Innovations, has said that it needs extra cash from governments for eight vaccine candidates in development. But Prof Andrew Pollard, of Oxford University, told MPs: ““I believe that six months is possible but it needs a lot of things to fall in place so that this process goes well.”Sunetra Gupta, a professor of theoretical epidemiology at Oxford, said: “We need to begin mass antibody testing to assess what stage of the epidemic weare in.”The government has purchased . million antibody tests, which could tellsomeone has ever had Covid-, and they will be kept at a centre in Milton Keynes, Bucks.

CUPRA, which is the performance arm of SEAT, is using state-of-the-art, multi-jet fusion technology to fashion parts in a fast and efficient way. The process of printing a mirror can take around  hours, but as they can print six at a time it gives the team the ability to create dferent designs simultaneously. This way they can quickly test the ying prototypes in a wind tunnel to find out which is best for aerodynamics. When taken to this controlled environment, the printed parts are fitted to the car and face winds of more than mph while sensors study the impact on inidual surfaces. The caraposs resistance data is displayed on screen and the engineers and designers compare the results for the dferent printed wing mirrors and grilles. As the smallest margins can make the dference in motorsport, it is crucial the D printed parts play their part in reducing fuel consumption while also increasing stability, speed and safety.Xavi Serra, head of technical development at CUPRA Racing, said: For the new CUPRA Leon Competici n we modelled the steering wheelaposs centre control module, the bonnet air vents, door mirrors and the brake and water cooling inlets. The main goal is to have a lot of parts in a short time. We can quickly test a wide iety of designs and furthermore, since vehicle development is now done in parallel, this technology enables us to react swtly to any changes in the design process.The bigger the iety of parts we can test in this facility, the better. The couple are already in Canada with their son Archie ready to officially begin their new non-royal lives. Many things will change from April , including their names. At the moment, they use their official HRH titles - which technically means they donapost have surnames. But as the Queen has said they must drop their titles as part of stepping back from their senior duties, they will have to use something . In the past, royals have often used their dukedoms as their surnames, with Princes William and Harry using Wales for school and their time in the military and George, Charlotte and Louis taking Cambridge. Meghan and Harry might keep using Sussex, but there are other options they might opt for instead. Harry might revert back to using Wales, which he used throughout his Army career, and Meghan may stick to her maiden name Markle - which is what she is still best known for. Or they could opt for something a little dferent, which would mean the whole family has the same name. Their son Archieaposs surname is Mountbatten-Windsor - the Royal Familyaposs official surname, which is used by all members who donapost have a title.  They adopted it back in  as a combination of Prince Philip and the Queenaposs names. Before marrying the Queen, Philip was Prince Philip of Greece and Denmark of the House of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg. However this wasnapost neutral enough so he adopted the name Mountbatten after his grandparents. When the then Princess Elizabeth had the coupleaposs first child Prince Charles, he assumed they would take on his name in the traditional way.  But Prime Minister Winston Churchill didnapost agree, and wanted them to continue to use the name Windsor, which was the official Royal Family surname. The Queenaposs grandmother Queen Mary agreed, and it caused such a row that the matter was even discussed in Parliament. In the end the Queen made the decision to go with her familyaposs views, and the name Windsor was used.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Queen has been pictured at Windsor Castle as she held her weekly audience with the Prime Minister by telephone.Pictures posted on Twitter by the Royal Family and the Prime Minister shows the Queen on an old fashioned phone in her Berkshire royal residence and Boris Johnson in his Downing Street office holding a phone to his ear. The weekly audience comes on the same day that Clarence House announced that the Prince of Wales has tested positive for coronavirus.Buckingham Palace said the Queen, , who is staying at Windsor Castle with the Duke of Edinburgh, , remains in good health and is following all appropriate advice. In the picture posted on Twitter, the monarch is in a room adorned with ornaments including a china corgi.Do you have a coronavirus story to share  Email webnews@mirrorThe royal familyaposs tweet said: The Queen held her weekly Audience with the Prime Minister today by telephone. Prince Charles developed symptoms over the weekend but otherwise remains in good health.  The heir to the throne met hundreds of people during a high number of engagements in recent weeks - where he offered namaste gestures instead of handshakes - but it is not possible to ascertain where he caught the virus, his spokesman said.  The Queen is expected to make a public address to the nation at some point in the coming weeks and is likely to pay tribute to health workers treating the sick, sympathise with bereaved families and offer support to the nation living with the restrictions aimed at combating the virus.Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall, , has tested negative for  coronavirus  and is self-isolating with her husband at their ,-acre Birkhall estate in Scotland, although they are apart from each other at the residence.Charles - who has since spoken to the Queen and sons William in Norfolk and Harry in Canada - is the first Royal Family member to be diagnosed with Covid-. He falls within one of the highest risk categories given his age. A Buckingham Palace spokeswoman said: Her majesty the Queen remains in good health.

story: NewsWoman ditched by text before wedding becomes mum alone thanks to sperm donorJade Edgington from Birmingham is now mum to baby Eden after deciding to go it alone when her fairytale wedding ended in heartacheShareCommentsByLucy NotarantonioKelly-Ann Mills:,  MAR NewsJade Edgington just after giving birth to baby Eden " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA young woman who was dumped her via text just months before her wedding day has become a mum thanks to a sperm donor. Jade Edgington was just six months away from her big day when the groom-to-be had a change of heart and shattered her dream of a fairytale ending. The business development manager spent the summer of  holidaying to take her mind off the break-up but her desire to be a mum never went away. After being diagnosed with polycystic oy syndrome, the -year-old knew her chances of conceiving naturally were slim and that sheaposd need IVF one day.  Jade, from Birmingham, West Mids, then made the bold decision to become a single parent with the help of IVF and a sperm donor.She says her le is now aposcompleteapos after giving birth to Eden last year on July .Jade says: I had known for a few years I had polycystic oy syndrome which meant that my oies had a lot of cysts all over them.My then partner seemed to be on the exact same wave and spoke about children and marriage from the very start. I felt like everything I had ever been waiting for was coming true. Until he randomly texted me to say he didnapost want to be with me - my entire world came crashing down.But that didnapost stop me from wanting to become a mum and it was the best decision I have ever made.I donapost have any regrets about doing this on my own and I feel like she has made me into the person I was always supposed to be.Jade was initially thrilled when her ex popped the question - nine months into their relationship and the pair went on to book their wedding for July . Jade recalls being on cloud nine in aposcoocoo landapos when booking her dream honeymoon to Thailand and Bali.But as the six month countdown approached, Jadeaposs ex-fiancee got cold feet. She said: He just changed his mind, as simple as that but kept me hanging for six weeks until he made his mind up about wanting to be with me or not.I was on a shoestring just wanting him to love me. I was distraught and genuinely broken.I put on a brave face when at work or with my friends and family but when I got home, I would sob and sob.But eventually I realised I deserve to be with someone who wants to be with me.I wasnapost willing to put myself into that situation ever again nor wait another few months or years to meet aposthe oneapos.I was still focussed on becoming a mum, evenit meant doing it alone. According to the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence fertility guidelines it is broadly recognised that single women are not eligible for IVF on the NHS.After thorough research, she found a clinic in Northern Spain and her journey to motherhood began.She adds: It was such a big decision and I had no idea where to find a clinic that is going to be the best at sucking my eggs out and sticking them back in fertilised!A friend had been to a dferent clinic in Spain but the country seemed to have higher success rates and was much cheaper.I found Manzanera Fertility Clinic in Northern Spain, and had my consultation via Skype in August [].I didnapost want to feel under pressure so I decided to keep it a secret from everyone but my dad Brian, , who accompanied me to to the clinic in October .Jade forked out £, of her savings to pay for IVF and she was able to get IVF medication in the UK.The clinic matched her characteristics to a sperm donoraposs to ensure her baby looked like her.She had three eggs fertilised but a pregnancy test two weeks later revealed one had stuck.
